name: Great Britain Alphabetically - Part B Quiz | Geography | 10 Questions

questions.text: Which city in northern England is home to the National Media Museum, the most visited museum in Britain outside of London?
questions.explanation:
Bradford.

	The National Media Museum, formerly known as the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television, opened in 1983. Bradford built its wealth on the textile industry during the industrial revolution of the 19th century.

questions.text: Which city in southwestern England is famed for its naturally occurring hot springs and Georgian architecture?
questions.explanation:
Bath.

	Bath was known to the Romans as Aquae Sulis, and its Roman Baths are still a major tourist attraction.

questions.text: Which town in Powys was formerly a county town, and shares its name with a range of mountains?
questions.explanation:
Brecon.

	Brecon was county town of Brecknockshire before local government reorganization in 1974. The Brecon Beacons, to the south of the town, were established as a National Park in 1957.

questions.text: Which English seaside resort is home to a Royal Pavilion, and a series of narrow winding streets called The Lanes, filled with antique shops?
questions.explanation:
Brighton.

	Brighton's Royal Pavilion was built for the then Prince of Wales, later King George IV, in the 1780s.

questions.text: Which is the second largest city in Great Britain, home to the Bull Ring shopping centre, and Edgbaston Cricket Ground?
questions.explanation:
Birmingham.

	Birmingham is also famed for, amongst other things, its Jewellery Quarter.

questions.text: Which famous seaside resort has a famous pleasure beach, which includes the Pepsi Max Big One, the tallest, fastest and steepest roller coaster in the world when it opened in 1994?
questions.explanation:
Blackpool.

	The Pepsi Max Big One lost its status as tallest, fastest and steepest roller coaster in the world in 1996, but Blackpool remains Britain's busiest seaside resort.

questions.text: Which Derbyshire town is famous for its mineral springs, and is known as the the 'gateway to the Peak District National Park'?
questions.explanation:
Buxton.

	In the 18th century, Buxton tried to rival Bath as a spa resort, and built a famous Georgian crescent similar to the one in the Somerset town.

questions.text: Which small Scottish town is famous for its castle, whose owner is the only person in Britain allowed to have his own private army?
questions.explanation:
Blair Atholl.

	Blair Castle is the seat of the Duke of Atholl, who has his own army, the Atholl Highlanders.

questions.text: Which town on the England-Scotland border has changed hands between the two countries 14 times?
questions.explanation:
Berwick-upon-Tweed.

	The city walls are a tourist attraction in Berwick, which finally became English in 1482.

questions.text: Which seaport was the birthplace of Isambard Kingdom Brunel's steamships, the Great Western, in 1837, and the Great Britain, in 1843; is the site of Brunel's Clifton Suspension Bridge, opened in 1864; and is home to Gloucestershire County Cricket Club?
questions.explanation:
Bristol.

	Bristol's main industries nowadays include the aerospace industry;  BAE Systems, Airbus and Rolls-Royce are all based at Filton on the northern outskirts of the city.
